awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Free Space Optics as Backhaul and Energizer for Drone-assisted Networking
awd_abstract_narration:
SoarNet (free Space Optics as bAckhaul and energizeR for drone-assisted NETworking) aims to simultaneously and rapidly transmit data and energy from an access node to a Drone-mounted Base Station (DBS), which can be flexibly deployed to provision wireless broadband access. That is, the DBS can simultaneously receive high-speed data streams and energy via optical beams. The received energy is used to power the DBS to prolong its flight and received data streams are delivered to Mobile Users (MUs) via existing Radio Frequency (RF) channels. SoarNet will be a game changer for mobile access. By leveraging Free Space Optics (FSO) communications and the drone-assisted mobile networking framework, SoarNet will significantly enhance the throughput of the network and Quality of Service (QoS) of MUs and will advance the state of the art of wireless networking and wireless charging. Proposed research activities will advance the understanding of simultaneously charging the DBS and transmitting data at high speed.

SoarNet comprises three major research endeavors. 1) Actualizing the SoarNet architecture to construct a FSO transmitter at an access node and a FSO receiver at a DBS to provision simultaneous energy transfer and data transmission; meanwhile, two mathematical models will be derived to estimate the charging rate by applying FSO as a charger and the transmission rate by applying FSO communications as wireless backhauling. 2) 3D DBS placement in SoarNet, to determine the longitude, latitude, and altitude of the DBS to maximize the throughput of delivering data to MUs in the access network, while guaranteeing the requirement of the DBS's charging rate. 3) Dynamic access node association and MU association, to associate the DBS with an access node (i.e., the DBS receives the data streams and energy from the access node) and adjusts the MU association area of the DBS (i.e., more/less MUs are associated with the DBS to download their data) in order to balance the traffic loads among access nodes, thus further improving the quality of service (QoS) in terms of the average delay of downloading data to MUs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project (SOARNET: free Space Optics as bAckhaul and energizeR for drone-assisted NETworking) has designed and developed a drone-mounted Base Station (DBS)-assisted heterogeneous network (HetNet) architecture and a series of advanced technologies that simultaneously and rapidly transmit data and energy from an access node (i.e., a macro base station (MBS)) to a DBS. This project has witnessed the development of a  Free Space Optics (FSO) receiver consisting of two concurrently operating subsystems: data relay and recharging systems. Various algorithms have been designed by exploiting both optimization and machine learning methods, such as deep-reinforcement learning, to carry out power control, flexible bandwidth and computing resources allocation, intelligent user association, DBS placement, and laser charging. As a result, various solutions have been offered to address many of the DBS-assisted networking problems with FSO-based backhaul and/or charging. Software simulation platforms and hardware testbeds have been developed to validate the viability of the developed solutions.

SOARNET, leveraging the FSO communications and drone-assisted mobile access networking framework, will not only significantly enhance the throughput of the mobile access network and Quality of Service (QoS) for Mobile Users (MUs) but will also broaden the benefits of wireless networking and optical charging. The associated research activities have greatly advanced the understanding of simultaneous recharging and high-speed data transmission/relaying. They have also investigated the subpar short battery life of DBSs and addressed the bottleneck in the wireless backhaul links. Moreover, technologies developed under SOARNET provide additional flexibility for mobile network operators with no additional cost for acquiring spectrum as FSO communications operates over an unlicensed spectrum. The main deliverables of SOARNET encompass 28 journal articles and 5 conference papers. Through SOARNET, among the nine Ph.D. students, one MS student and one undergraduate student who have participated in the project, three have successfully defended their doctoral dissertations and acknowledged the NSF support in their dissertations. This project has trained and prepared these students well for cutting-edge work in both the research and industrial communities.

In summary, SOARNET has achieved the following:

1)     Various algorithms have been designed by exploiting both optimization and machine learning methods, such as deep-reinforcement learning, to carry out, such as deep actor-critic reinforcement learning-based power control, adjustable flexible bandwidth and computing resources allocation, intelligent user association, smart DBS placement, and laser charging to optimize the performance of a DBS-assisted HetNet utilizing FSO for backhauling and recharging.

2)     The FSO charging and communication models have been studied in great depth.

3)     A novel traffic load balancing framework has been developed to strike an optimal balance between the MBS and the DBS. In addition, to minimize the average latency ratio of all MUs, a scheme to determine the location of the DBS, the user association and the bandwidth allocation has been developed.

4)     The laser charging-enabled DBS-assisted wireless communications network has been designed to enable simultaneous communications and charging between the DBS and the core network. Based on the designed architecture, a novel joint power and bandwidth allocation (JPB) scheme and a counting placement algorithm have been designed to maximize the total data rate.

5)     A novel DBS-aided HetNet framework with in-band full-duplex (IBFD) communications for 5G -based uplink and downlink communications has been designed. In addition, a (1-ε)-approximation algorithm for the 3D DBS placement, user assignment, and bandwidth and power allocation has been developed.

6)     The DBS-enabled edge computing architecture has been designed to provision Internet of Things Devices (IoTD) service to maximize the total Quality of Experience (QoE). Based on that, two deep reinforcement learning methods have been developed to solve the UAV trajectory problem.

7)     An FSO-enabled DBS-assisted HetNet architecture has been proposed. Based on the proposed architecture, the DBS utilizes FSO communications for backhauling and recharging concurrently, thus prolonging the service time of the DBS and improving the network throughput without introducing interference to the access link, while guaranteeing the MUs' QoS requirements.

8)     A novel algorithm based on a series of convex approximation has been formulated to exploit the 5G New Radio (NR) numerology schemes in a DBS-assisted Internet-of-Things (IoT) network to assign flexible RB bandwidths to IoT devices (IoTDs) for mobile edge computing in a latency-sensitive scenario where devices offload their computational tasks to a hovering DBS. Both flexible RB bandwidth and computation resource assignments are carried out on a per-device basis to maximize the spectral efficiency, resource block tiling in the wireless resource-time grid and minimize the network's energy consumption.

9)     The completion time within a UAV-enabled IoT network has been investigated. Time was discretized into slots to optimize IoT device association, UAV trajectory, and velocity. Overcoming non-convexity and an unknown number of slots, a deep deterministic policy gradient approach has been designed to effectively tackle the resulting high-dimensional, continuous control problems.
